comment.narrative: Effective conservation planning for the Asiatic cheetah is still limited by a lack of detailed basic data on the cheetah itself and on its prey species. There is no detailed biological/ecological knowledge available based on robust statistical methods that is analysed and reported according to scientific standards. There is still no reliable population estimate of the Asiatic cheetah. In addition, many sites still lack comprehensive socio-economic data. Addressing the data and information gaps that is required for effective conservation planning is a long-term and continual endeavor. In the interim, a number of protected areas that are home to cheetah and its prey require sustenance and possibly augmentation of physical protection.

description.narrative: Objective: To conserve the biodiversity in the Central Zagros Landscape Conservation Zone

%ge of the Zone under a management regime addressing mainstreaming biodiversity conservation( THIS INDICATOR IS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/ UNDP APPROVALS)
BIODIVERSITY RICH FOREST, RANGELAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS ARE CONSERVED AND RESTORED IN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS ACCORDING TO SPECIFICATIONS AND AREAS MAPPED IN MANAGEMENT PLANS (NEW)

comment.narrative: BASELINE SURVEYS OF HABITATS IN PMA CONSERVATION & RESTORATION AREAS TO BE CONDUCTED

HABITAT CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS TOTALING AT LEAST 10,000 HA IN EACH PMA ESTABLISHED AND FUNCTIONING SUPPORTED BY FINANCING, PARTICIPATORY MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING MECHANISMS BY END OF 2016 (NEW)

- The total area of Central Zagros Mountains (CZM) under study was extended after revision from 2.500.000 ha to 3.100.000 ha and 10 catchment management areas (CMAs) were designated to be managed (Long-term and macro scale), and the scaling-up of the long term CZM management system started in 2 phases: First, in 2015, 4 PMAs, i.e. 393.465 ha, were extended to 4 CMAs with the total area of 1.629.000 ha. At the second phase, the remaining 6 CMAs (not included in the former PMAs), will be considered as a part of scaling up in 2016.

description.narrative:
Population of selected key flagship species (Persian squirrel and bear) ( THIS INDICATOR IS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/ UNDP APPROVALS)
POPULATION OF SELECTED FLAGSHIP SPECIES (FAUNA AND FLORA) IN BD HOTSPOTS ACROSS THE ZONE
CHANGE IN STATUS OF INDICATOR SPECIES IN PMA CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS RELATED TO THE FOLLOWING ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS:
a) RANGELAND DEGRADATION (SELECTED FLORA AND BUTTERFLY SPECIES SENSITIVE TO OVERGRAZING)
b) FOREST DEGRADATION AND LOSS (DENSITY OF REGENERATING SEEDLINGS OF DOMINANT TREE SPECIES (EG PERSIAN OAK))
c) RIVERINE HABITAT DEGRADATION (EURASIAN OTTER)
d) HUNTING PRESSURE (CHUKAR PARTRIDGE)
(NEW INDICATOR)

comment.narrative: TO BE DETERMINED THROUGH BASELINE SURVEYS IN SAMPLING AREAS
STABLE OR INCREASING POPULATION TRENDS IN SAMPLING AREAS BY THE END OF 2016 (NEW)

- A total of 940.60 ha, of forest and rangelands of the CZM has been occupied, fired, degreased, and charcoal made during this period of PIR, a two-fold reduction in comparison with the 2014 PIR.
- A total of 4300 ha of Oak forest inside CZM is rehabilitated by FRWO to recover the forest habitats which have been affected by Oak Die Back disease.
- Illegal hunting of birds is reported 10 numbers, also DoE reported the total number of watched choker partridgeâ€™ population 121 (Naghan-Boldagi),
- The population of Wild Goat is 4483 which has been raised for four times and the total number of chukar partridgeâ€™ population is 276 (West Dena),
- Rehabilitation 10 K.ms of Eurasian otter Habitat along Marbor River (Dena Vanak),
- The population of Wild goat in Margoon is 9 (Kor Kamfirouz),

- Implementation seven conservation and sustainable livelihood projects namely:

o Develop sustainable livelihood action plan in Naqan-Buldaji and build the capacity of 45 rural female and 56 rural male from four villages for development ecological livelihood namely planting medical herbs, carpet, mushroom, beekeeping, compost, sewing local clothes.
o â€œsustainable ecotourismâ€ in Kor-Kamfirouz including build capacity for 20 rural youth as CBO in Mengan Village, equip and establish three eco-lodge, wild watching cottages and handicraft shop, and also entertain four groups of visitors.
o â€œRural Handicrafts developmentâ€ in Naqan-Buldaji including capacity development for the 20 female villagers and forming the Sholiz CBO, conduct local/ provincial and national handicraft exhibitions, marketing and provide income for female villagers and involve them in rehabilitation of Oak forest.
o "Rehabilitation and conservation of medical herbs" in Dena Vanakincluding planting of 12000 seeds of Dracocephalum kotschyi Boiss & Thymus daenenss, and build the capacity for 10 nomads and support them in marketing,
o â€œ2nd phase of IPCM (Integrated Participatory Crop Management)â€ in Kor-Kamfirouz, including establish six CBO (25 villagers in each group) through infrastructures in 6 core villages. The result has been disseminated to all CZM provinces by the MOJA to be included in their annual program.
o Conduct the study for â€œAnalyzing the effect of environmental factors on the implementation of the fungi in the mass of Oak Forest die back in Iranâ€ in West Dena by the cooperation of FRWO. Based on the first report Yasuj University came to this idea that the bacteria as the secondary factor in Oak Die Back not a Fungi.

description.narrative: Increase in best-practice, organic and traditional/local innovations in land and water management, biodiversity conservation and climate change resilience ,

comment.narrative: Current use measured in Y1
8 innovations at demonstration sites

8 innovations at demonstration sites were established (one new in this reporting period that is producing 4 solar driers to demonstrate in each pilot sites)
Traditionally extra vegetable and fruits were dried to be kept for a longer course of time. The system they used to it is not hygienic, market acceptable, and healthy. Solar food dehydrator is a simple set which led the farmer to dry their materials in dust and insect free environment. Fruits and vegetable are dried in shade to keep their essential oils and vitamins. It help rural to take benefit of sun and there is no need of other sources such as fuel which is getting more expensive these days. This set is suitable for a gardener who has one or more fruit garden. Result of primarily tests is satisfactory and local people are interested to make more sets for their own
Current use measured in Y1
Increased by at least 30%

This organization is responsible for implementing the strategies.

title.narrative: Third Nat'l Comm to UN Climate Change Convention

description.narrative: Enabling the Islamic Republic of Iran to prepare its Third National Communication to the Conference of Parties (CoP) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
Iran's Self Assessment for the preparation of the Third National Communication (TNC) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
independent political entity

Preparation and submission of Iran's Third National Communication GHG inventory with Tier 2 data for key sources and national emission factors Establishment of continuous data measurement and analysis system Complete inventory chapter for the TNC for the year 2010. Compiling the GHGs emission inventory at provincial level for 2013 and 2014. Climate scenarios that reflect current information and modeling techniques Complete V&A chapter of the TNC National Adaptation Programme (NAPs) -contingent National Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs)- Contingent Complete mitigation chapter of TNC Project profiles on mitigation and adaptation for funding by any international sources such as GCF, GEF, etc. Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) for Adaptation Establish institutional arrangement for climate change at DOE and relevant organizations Allocation of national budgets to plan and implement mitigation and adaptation measures

comment.narrative: Over recent years, the GoI has paid significant attention to environmental sustainability issues, in particular to those relating to climate change. The government of Iran has ratified the UNFCCC in July 1996 and on 16 October 1996 became a Non-Annex I party to the Convention. Iran also ratified the Kyoto Protocol on 22 August 2005 and established the Designated National Authority (DNA) for CDM in October 2006. Iran has submitted its Initial National Communication (INC) to UNFCCC in March 2003 and has submitted its Second National Communication (SNC). Two major Rules of Procedure were prepared by the Department of Environment (DOE) and approved by the Cabinet in August, 2009 and November, 2010 respectively to regulate the implementation of the UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol as well as to regulate development of Clean Development Mechanism projects.

title.narrative: HCFC Phase Out Management Plan for Iran

description.narrative: HCFC Phase out Management Plan for Iran
HCFC phase-out Management Plan-Stage I
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity

1. The XIXth Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol in September 2007, through its Decision XIX/6, adopted an accelerated phase-out schedule for HCFCs. The first control is the freeze on production and consumption of HCFCs from 01 January 2013, at the Baseline Level (average of 2009 and 2010 consumption levels). The second control step is the reduction of 10% from the Baseline Levels on 01 January 2015. 2. Preparation of HCFC Phase-out Management Plans (HPMP).

comment.narrative: During the implementation of the CFC phase-out under the Montreal Protocol, HCFCs were approved as interim substitutes for CFCs in many of the projects and activities supported by the MLF. HCFCs, which have an ODP upto 15 % of CFCs are however classified as controlled substances under Annex-C, Group-I of the Montreal Protocol. HCFCs, therefore, have use restrictions and would eventually have to be phased-out. Iran does not produce HCFCs and the domestic demand is entirely met through imports. The total imports of HCFCs in Iran during 2005 were 2,114 metric tonnes. At conservative growth rates, and in the absence of this project, HCFC consumption is projected to reach about 8,293 metric tonnes by 2015.

description.narrative: To put in place a collaborative governance system and know-how for managing a mosaic of land uses in the Caspian Hyrcanian forest that provides habitat integrity and helps maintain landscape level ecosystem functions and resilience.
Landscape area in the Caspian Hyrcanian forests where forestry and other production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: 0 ha
Policy and regulatory frameworks for managing multiple use forest landscapes across~ 800,000 ha of forests

Policy and regulatory frameworks have been reviewed through project financial resources to explore gaps for integration and mainstreaming of participatory multipurpose forestry and biodiversity conservation in sectoral policies, laws and regulations as well as institutional mechanisms such as monitoring and law enforcement systems. The study is at the final stages and it's expected to suggest amendments to policies, laws and regulations and institutional mechanisms. The study suggests that there are almost no barrier in policies, laws and regulatory frameworks to prevent FRWO and other government agencies to apply participatory forest management. The study is also encouraging the parliament to approve the national "Comprehensive Natural Resources Law" which is awaiting the final steps in there. A number of suggestions will come out of the study to enrich the regulatory framework of forest management. These suggestions will go to the Forest High Council for further action and taking into practice. In addition, the project contributed to development of relevant articles of the 6th National Development Plan and incorporated participatory multipurpose forestry in its draft version as a mandate for all government sectors during 2016-20.

description.narrative: Area of biodiversity set-asides created governed by clear specific management guidelines

comment.narrative: Some areas (~ 10%) are under biodiversity set-asides but without any systematic management regime for biodiversity conservation
At least 100,000 ha of new biodiversity set asides under FRWO management defined (with management guidelines)

FRWO is managing Forest Reserves and Forest Parks in which rare plant species are conserved and protected. The idea of BD Set-asides puts forward a holistic mechanism through which both Fauna and Flora are under management regimes by FRWO. Aiming at developing management regimes for better management of biodiversity in the whole Caspian Hyrcanina Area, "Special Areas for Biodiversity" - SABs will be established in consultation with FRWO technical divisions and DoE as the main relevant stakeholder. SABs will be managed based on modern Biosphere Reserve model to ensure conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity (Fauna and Flora). A concept note has been developed on designing and management of SABs which was consulted in an inclusive biodiversity workshop. Potential SABs have been initially mapped by relevant stakeholders and draft codes of practice prepared in a participatory manner. Potential sites will be further studied and 100,000 ha of area will be assigned and designated as SABs by Forest High Council by mid-2016. Further steps will be taken to register SABs as biosphere reserves after the approval of the Forest High-Council.

Impacts of these capacity development practices will be measured in the mid-term of the project implementation.

description.narrative: Extent and quality of forest cover IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative:
Incidents of illicit felling involving creaming of commercially important species;
Clearance of forest areas for agriculture leading to 0.5% loss of forests
No net loss of forest cover and improved quality with reduced loss of high grade species

Forest degradation is not only due to deforestation but also is mainly because of depletion of the forest quality. There is no single indicator based on which one can assess the quality of forest. Therefore, further to conducting forest cover assessment through remote sensing methods, the project arranged a comprehensive forest condition assessment through which 16 different forest parameters were measured. The field study is finished and report writing is in final stages. Forest quality parameters have been measured in pilot landscapes in the FRWO network of permanent monitoring plots with an area of 1,000 square meters. Forest cover and biodiversity parameters were also measured in the same network to be attributable. The study will be repeated at the end of the project implementation for comparing results.

description.narrative: STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative: SPECIES AND BASELINE TO BE SET IN 2014
NO DECLINE IN STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES BY END OF PROJECT

No change is expected to be measured in this stage. Based on discussions with the biodiversity consultants as well as project CTA and approval of project board changes of biodiversity status and trends could not be measured in short periods. Hence biodiversity survey will be repeated at the end of the project to assess the changes against the baseline. Status of mammals is under study in all four pilot landscapes. The study is focused on a few number of flagship species like Red Deer, Roe Deer, Persian Leopard, Wolf, Wild Boar and Brown Bear. Mammals study is also addressing human-wildlife conflicts which is a very important cause for killing of animals and will be concluded with a plan for conflict resolution in each of the pilot landscapes.

description.narrative: An enabling policy and regulatory framework for multiple use forest management is developed
INTER-SECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED, National policy and regulatory framework is adjusted to meet BD mainstreaming requirements and is updated within operational procedures

comment.narrative: FRWO and other FMPs are not coordinated and lack inclusion of biodiversity conservation practices

INTER-SECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED AT HYRCANIAN FOREST AND PILOT LANDSCAPE LEVELS
1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning issued

Local Coordination Committees (LCCs) have been regularly meeting on a quarterly basis as the main inter-sectoral coordination mechanism at the local level. LCCs have been heavily involved in development of Integrated Management Plans (IMPs) which ensures functioning of the mechanism. Regional Coordination Committee (RCC) was established as the main driver for inter-sectoral and inter-provincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests. The latter makes sure a harmonized approach between all three Caspian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape through development and implementation of the so called "Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy". The Strategy is under preparation after the first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline. Implementation of the "Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy" will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme. The study on policies, laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015.

description.narrative: INTEGRATED, MULTI-PURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN, INCLUDING sustainable land use plan defines a clear direction for the Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and supports mainstreaming biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Land use plans exist at the basin/catchment levels under FRWO management and similar plans exist for DoE management of PAs. However, a coordinated plan for production sectors does not exist

INTEGRATED, MULTI-PURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN, INCLUDING Sustainable land use plan for Caspian Hyrcanian forest, that a) define biodiversity rich areas to be gazetted as new PAs and b) lay out appropriate land-uses and management practices to be prescribed in the adjacent production landscape

To ensure inter-sectoral and inter-provincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and adoption of a harmonized approach between all three Casian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape, a so called "Hyrcanian Forest Green Development Strategy" is under preparation. The first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline. Implementation of the "Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy" will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme. The study on policies, laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015. The Strategy will include a zoning plan for the whole Caspian area which will locate the main land-use categories across the whole region. The Zoning Plan is also under preparation.

description.narrative: Operational guidelines are being utilised to manage multiple land uses in forest landscapes, including improved forestry, small holder agriculture and livestock practices

comment.narrative: Forestry, tourism and agriculture sectors lack a coordinated approach to management
At least 3 improved operational guidelines for: i) improved forestry; ii) sustainable small holder agriculture; iii) improved livestock practices and iv) sustainable tourism

As the sectoral guidelines should encompass best practices and lessons learned, preparation of these guidelines will be subject to slight postponement. Development of guidelines starts in the second half of 2015. ToR for national coordinating consultant is drafted ad under finalization.

description.narrative: Extent of integration of ecosystem values into production sector strategies and plans

comment.narrative: Ecosystem goods and services are utilised by production sectors, however their true ecological value is not understood or incorporated into the economics of key production sectors
Systematic analysis of values of forests and externalities of deforestation and forest degradation incorporated into sector decisions and finance options identified to offset opportunity costs.

Ecosystem services in pilot landscapes have been mapped by application of a novel tool called "InVest" software. The software is used for the first time ever in the country which offers visual understanding of ecosystem services in two scenarios of present and future. The future scenario can be used as a supporting tool for decision making in pilot landscapes. economic values of ecosystem services are being calculated which will be followed by designing of financial options under Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES). The whole set of study is being conducted by a team of national consultants and supervision of international consultant. The study will be finalized by Q2 2016. The study has been involving relevant stakeholders (mainly Government entities) in training and consultation sessions and helped a lot in raising the awareness an building capacities on ecosystem services and their economic values .

comment.narrative: At least 3

Project training plan is recently drafted. 2 comprehensive trainings on social forestry and ecosystem services values have been offered during the reporting period. Consultation sessions to develop IMPs, SABs proposal and Social Forestry Roadmap have been conducted through which training and capacity building modules have been offered. At least 300 people from different line sectors and local community representatives attended all these training and consultative sessions during the reporting period. MoU is under finalization to be signed between the project and Training and Public Participation Bureau of FRWO for joint collaboration and inclusion of relevant trainings in the official induction and in-service training programmes of FRWO.

Integrated Management Plans were drafted for all 4 pilot landscapes in a participatory manner. All stakeholder groups including government agencies, NGOs, academia and local communities contributed in development of IMPs through 14 different training and consultative sessions. IMPs need further consultation with local communities and the target is to approve them in LCCs and PPDCs by end 2015. Implementation of IMPs will start from 2016.

comment.narrative: Community based forests require support for monitoring
Effective monitoring systems in place to control harvesting forest resources

The study to review existing monitoring and enforcement mechanisms initiated and will be finalized in Q3 2015. The final conclusion of the study will be a number of proposals and a step-wise roadmap to adjust and amend existing mechanisms and make them more effective and aligned with multipurpose forest management requirements.

description.narrative: Community based integrated forest management piloted
Number of activities included in the alternative livelihood development strategy that are implemented and percentage increase in income of community groups

comment.narrative:
0
Income baseline of community groups will be established during the first year

At least 4 different types of alternative livelihood activities such as beekeeping, NTFP enterprise, rural handicrafts, aquaculture, dairy product marketing etc. [to be further selected from the PPG shortlist during IW]
At least 15-20 % increase in income of targeted community groups

The alternative Livelihood Strategy is still under preparation in a consultative manner and based on in-depth and comprehensive data and knowledge that the project gained in all four pilot landscapes. Feasibility of low impact eco-tourism is being assessed in all four pilots and the study is expected to come to an end in 3 months. However, alternative livelihood options is being taken in two of the pilot landscapes. 6 women groups in Chehelchai are progressively making handicrafts and selling them under their name and brand. Handicrafts are made from local materials and have roots in their culture. Women groups have been able to generate significant amount of income as much as $5,000 during the reporting period. In project pilot landscape in Guilan Province, two youth groups was established which are taking alternative options for income generation. One group is developing its skills to do eco-tourism activities. The group has been able to take two groups of local tourists to the vicinity forest. The other group tried to establish a nursery to produce seedlings of forest species. Because of some legal challenges they have changed the idea and are trying to grow mushrooms as another alternative.

description.narrative: Number of community based forest management plans developed, AGREED BY COMMUNITY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES and implemented

comment.narrative: 2 COMMUNITY BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS COVERING 30,000HA

FRWO has been practicing traditional forestry activities for several decades. There are significant resistances against application of Community Forestry (CF) in technical and managerial disciplines of FRWO. On the other hand local communities lack enough capacities to engage in CF planning and implementation. The project has organized an introductory session on CF followed by a comprehensive training on this topic aiming at building capacities in FRWO for CF and reducing resistances. Local communities have been a;so exposed to the idea during the reporting period. It's expected that development of CF plans will start towards the end of 2015 in limited areas first n Chehelchai and Sehezar pilots and then in Baliran. In Fariroud, Narvan cooperative is doing CF which needs adjustments to bring inclusiveness and equity. There seem to be willingness to apply these amendments. The project will start facilitation for these adjustments towards the end 2015.

description.narrative: Number of people shifting to alternative livelihood options that reduce pressure on biodiversity

comment.narrative: Baseline to be collected in Year 1
TARGET TO BE DEFINED IN 2014 AFTER DESIGN OF ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS PLAN

In total 8 groups of local communities (6 women groups and 2 youth groups) started adoption of alternative livelihoods to reduce the pressure over forest landscapes. Alternative Livelihood Strategy is under preparation and will be finalized in Q3 2015.

The baseline for forest clearance is under preparation through socio-economic and forest condition assessment studies. Both studies will be finalized by Q3 2015.
